headline: Disney tops earnings forecasts with streaming gains, raises guidance
summary: STORY: Walt Disney posted better-than-expected quarterly results on Wednesday (August 6).And the entertainment giant raised its annual profit forecast.Adjusted earnings per share rose 16% from a year ago to $1.61 for Disney's fiscal third quarter - well above analyst expectations.The update was led by gains in its streaming business.Disney projected it would add 10 million Disney+ and Hulu subscribers in the current quarter.Subscriptions for both rose by 2.6 million to 183 million in the quarter just ended.That drove a 6% rise in revenue at the direct-to-consumer business.Disney also announced two major deals with the National Football League and WWE over the last 24 hours.That as it gets ready for its just under $30 per month ESPN streaming service later this month.The WWE deal will bring exclusive rights to major wrestling events to the streaming service.The NFL will take a 10% equity stake in Disney's ESPN sports network.The company has been building its streaming business in sports and entertainment while traditional television viewing falls.It's also expanded its popular theme parks and cruise lines.Disney's parks division reported a 13% gain in income to $2.5 billion.Profit at domestic parks rose more than a fifth even with new competition in Orlando, Florida, from Universal's Epic Universe.However, operating income in the entertainment division fell 15% to $1 billion.Disney blamed the drop on lower results from traditional television networks and the strong performance of the film "Inside Out 2" a year earlier.

raw.headline: Disney tops earnings forecasts with streaming gains, raises guidance
raw.summary: STORY: Walt Disney posted better-than-expected quarterly results on Wednesday (August 6).And the entertainment giant raised its annual profit forecast.Adjusted earnings per share rose 16% from a year ago to $1.61 for Disney's fiscal third quarter - well above analyst expectations.The update was led by gains in its streaming business.Disney projected it would add 10 million Disney+ and Hulu subscribers in the current quarter.Subscriptions for both rose by 2.6 million to 183 million in the quarter just ended.That drove a 6% rise in revenue at the direct-to-consumer business.Disney also announced two major deals with the National Football League and WWE over the last 24 hours.That as it gets ready for its just under $30 per month ESPN streaming service later this month.The WWE deal will bring exclusive rights to major wrestling events to the streaming service.The NFL will take a 10% equity stake in Disney's ESPN sports network.The company has been building its streaming business in sports and entertainment while traditional television viewing falls.It's also expanded its popular theme parks and cruise lines.Disney's parks division reported a 13% gain in income to $2.5 billion.Profit at domestic parks rose more than a fifth even with new competition in Orlando, Florida, from Universal's Epic Universe.However, operating income in the entertainment division fell 15% to $1 billion.Disney blamed the drop on lower results from traditional television networks and the strong performance of the film "Inside Out 2" a year earlier.

headline: ESPN and the NFL Reach New Agreements To Extend NFL Draft Rights and Add NFL Content and Features to ESPN’s Upcoming Direct-to-Consumer Service
summary: NEW YORK & BRISTOL, Conn., August 06, 2025--ESPN and the NFL have reached new licensing agreements, extending ESPN’s NFL Draft rights and, separately, adding NFL programming and content to ESPN’s upcoming Direct-to-Consumer (DTC) service, as well as to Disney+. The agreement also includes the opportunity for fans to bundle ESPN’s DTC service with NFL+ Premium.

raw.headline: ESPN and the NFL Reach New Agreements To Extend NFL Draft Rights and Add NFL Content and Features to ESPN’s Upcoming Direct-to-Consumer Service
raw.summary: NEW YORK & BRISTOL, Conn., August 06, 2025--ESPN and the NFL have reached new licensing agreements, extending ESPN’s NFL Draft rights and, separately, adding NFL programming and content to ESPN’s upcoming Direct-to-Consumer (DTC) service, as well as to Disney+. The agreement also includes the opportunity for fans to bundle ESPN’s DTC service with NFL+ Premium.

headline: ESPN’s Direct-to-Consumer Service and Enhanced App Launching August 21
summary: BRISTOL, Conn., August 06, 2025--ESPN will launch its new previously announced direct-to-consumer streaming service on Thursday, August 21, bringing the full suite of ESPN networks and services – within an enhanced ESPN App with new, personalized features and functionality – directly to fans.

raw.headline: ESPN’s Direct-to-Consumer Service and Enhanced App Launching August 21
raw.summary: BRISTOL, Conn., August 06, 2025--ESPN will launch its new previously announced direct-to-consumer streaming service on Thursday, August 21, bringing the full suite of ESPN networks and services – within an enhanced ESPN App with new, personalized features and functionality – directly to fans.

headline: Disney Paying $1.6 Billion for WWE Rights
summary: Disney’s  ESPN and  TKO Group’s  World Wrestling Entertainment have reached a more than $1.6 billion agreement that will give the sports-media company exclusive rights to many of WWE’s most high profile events.  The five-year deal, which will begin in 2026, includes the U.S. streaming rights to major events including WrestleMania and SummerSlam.  ESPN will pay $325 million a year for the rights, according to people familiar with the matter.

raw.headline: Disney Paying $1.6 Billion for WWE Rights
raw.summary: Disney’s  ESPN and  TKO Group’s  World Wrestling Entertainment have reached a more than $1.6 billion agreement that will give the sports-media company exclusive rights to many of WWE’s most high profile events.  The five-year deal, which will begin in 2026, includes the U.S. streaming rights to major events including WrestleMania and SummerSlam.  ESPN will pay $325 million a year for the rights, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: ESPN, WWE Reach Landmark Rights Agreement as ESPN Platforms Become Exclusive U.S. Domestic Home of All WWE Premium Live Events, Including WrestleMania, Starting in 2026
summary: BRISTOL, Conn. & STAMFORD, Conn., August 06, 2025--ESPN, a subsidiary of The Walt Disney Company (NYSE: DIS), and WWE, part of TKO Group Holdings, Inc. (NYSE: TKO), today announced a landmark rights agreement as ESPN platforms, including the new ESPN direct-to-consumer streaming service, will become the exclusive U.S. domestic home of all WWE Premium Live Events (PLEs), including the two-night cultural phenomenon WrestleMania, starting in 2026. This deal makes ESPN home to the highest-profile WW

headline: Disney's ESPN Scores Big With NFL Network Acquisition
summary: ESPN, a subsidiary of The Walt Disney Company (NYSE:DIS), is set to take over NFL Network and several other league-owned media assets, including NFL RedZone and NFL Fantasy, in a groundbreaking equity-for-assets deal with the National Football League (NFL). In return, the NFL will receive a 10% ownership stake in ESPN. Disney aims to fold these NFL properties into its expanding digital offerings and upcoming direct-to-consumer platform. ESPN will integrate NFL Network into its new streaming serv
